Legal_Issue: Whether 'B BEYMEN' is confusingly similar to Hudson's Bay's 'BAY/BAIE' trademarks
Evidence_Assessment: Hudson's Bay provided evidence of extensive use and advertising; Beymen lacks Canadian market presence
Burden_of_Proof: On Hudson's Bay as opponent to demonstrate likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: New evidence submitted by Hudson's Bay on appeal
Legal_Rule: Confusion assessed based on distinctiveness, usage history, nature of goods/services, trade, and resemblance
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on issue type (implied)
Procedural_Issue: Admissibility of new evidence on appeal
Grounds_for_Claim: Likelihood of consumer confusion due to phonetic and visual similarity
Outcome_on_Merits: Partial success for Hudson's Bay; restriction placed on Beymen’s mark
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Opposition initially rejected, then partially upheld on appeal
Review_Standard: Assessment based on statutory factors under Section 6
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Board’s initial rejection followed by court review with new evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Usage and advertising history of 'BAY/BAIE'; lack of Canadian presence for 'BEYMEN'
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, specifically Trade-Marks Act
Court_Result: Allowed in part – 'B BEYMEN' restricted to certain wares/services
Defendant_Response: Beymen proceeded with application despite opposition
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of use and advertising
Outcome: Partial restriction on Beymen's trademark rights
Remedy_Sought: Limitation or refusal of Beymen's trademark application
Authority: Canadian courts and Trademark Opposition Board
Governing_Rule: Section 6 of the Trade-Marks Act regarding confusion
